awd_titl_txt: Math Skills and Affective Domain Interventions to Improve Success for Female Students in Geoscience Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
Women continue to be underrepresented in the geosciences at the undergraduate level and in the workforce. Yet, there has been limited research to identify barriers that decrease persistence of women in geoscience fields. This project will examine whether or not math is a barrier to female student persistence and success in geosciences. Results of this project may provide information that can be used to increase student performance in geoscience courses and improve persistence in the geoscience majors.  In this way, the project aims to support the overarching goal of broadening participation of women in geoscience fields. 

A lack of math skills and/or negative affective domain factors may affect female students' performance in introductory geoscience classes and reduce their persistence in a geoscience major. This project will identify successful instructional interventions that best improve female students' performance in geoscience classes and persistence in a geoscience major.  The project proposes two specific objectives to accomplish this goal.  The first objective is to develop and implement math skills and affective domain interventions in geoscience classes. The project plans three interventions.  Intervention A will focus on improving affective characteristics (e.g., increase self-efficacy; reduce anxiety).  Intervention B will provide academic support in math via "The Math You Need, When You Need It" modules.  These modules were developed by one of the project investigators and are publicly available through the Science Education Resource Center.  Intervention C will combine both affective and math support interventions. The second objective is to examine the impact of these interventions on student performance in geoscience classes and persistence in geoscience. Results of this study will identify the impact of the three interventions on student performance, including which intervention is most successful in improving the performance of female undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to broaden the participation and success of female students in undergraduate geoscience courses and programs. This project also addressed the limited research on math attitudes and skills as barriers for women in undergraduate geoscience programs. Two objectives addressed those goals: Objective 1) to develop and implement new interventions focused on math attitudes and math skills in introductory geoscience courses to improve student success and persistence, with a particular emphasis on promoting female student success and persistence; and Objective 2) to determine the impact of the interventions on student attitudes, math skills, and persistence in geoscience majors. Research on the effectiveness of the interventions filled a gap in the research about which of those approaches (affective domain lessons only, math skills lessons only, or a combination of affective domain and math skills lessons) is better at improving female student success in geoscience. The research findings provided insight into whether math is a barrier to student success and what factors most influenced the persistence of female students. 


To address Objective 1, six novel lessons were developed. The new lessons addressed important affective domain issues related to math anxiety: geoscience self-efficacy, math anxiety, geoscience interest, goal planning, metacognition, and stereotype threat. The affective domain lessons were named “Geoscience Success Lesson.” Six math skills lessons from “The Math You Need, When You Need It” were also adapted for this project. We implemented the new affective domain lessons and the math skills lessons in three interventions (affective domain lessons only, math lessons only, and affective domain and math lessons) in introductory and advanced geology labs taught at three postsecondary institutions: one community college and two regional universities. 


To address Objective 2, a multi-method research study was implemented to examine students’ math anxiety experiences and the impact of the interventions on students’ affective domain, math skills, and persistence in geoscience. Through analysis of students’ written math narratives about their feelings, physiological reactions, and thoughts, the study identified three integrated math anxiety experience themes: Thriving, Agonizing, and Persisting. Thriving students liked math and had positive assessments of themselves in math. Agonizing students had negative feelings, thoughts, and physiological reactions related to math. Persisting students had positive and negative feelings and thoughts, but believed they could persist in math. A higher percentage of women than men held Agonizing integrated math anxiety experiences, and a lower percentage of women than men held Thriving integrated math anxiety experiences. Students in introductory geoscience classes had a range of integrated math anxiety experiences, which may have an important role in their success and in their decisions to take additional geoscience classes.


Results of survey data analyses show that students’ interest in geoscience was most strongly predicted by their self-efficacy in geoscience. For women, but not men, self-efficacy in mathematics was a significant predictor of their interest in geoscience. Math anxiety did not significantly predict students’ interest in geoscience. However, math anxiety did predict students’ self-efficacy and interest in geoscience. The Geoscience Success Lesson intervention (affective domain only lessons) significantly improved students’ self-efficacy in mathematics from before to after completing the lessons. These results provide new knowledge about the role of math attitudes in geoscience and ways to reduce math as a barrier for these students.


The findings from this project reveal the role of math attitude in geoscience, suggest avenues for addressing potential barriers to female student success, and inform geoscience educators of essential factors to students’ success.
